# Compare $F_E$ and $F_G$


:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.callout-important icon=false}
## Electricity
$$\boxed{F_E=k\frac{q_1 q_2}{r^2}}$$
$$k=9.0\times10^9\text{Nm}^2/\text{C}^2$$
$$q \text{ is the object's charge}$$
::: 
:::
::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.callout-tip icon=false}
## Gravity
$$\boxed{F_G=k\frac{m_1 m_2}{r^2}}$$
$$G=6.7\times10^{-11}\text{Nm}^2/\text{kg}^2$$
$$m \text{ is the object's mass}$$
:::
:::
::::

The electric force is similar to the gravitational force.

Charge can be positive or negative, but mass is only positive.

# Solar Neutrino Problem {.smaller}

1st detectors saw 1/3 of expected neutrinos from the Sun.
Turns out neutrinos oscillate between three types of neutrinos


:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="35%"}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
![Neutrinos come in three flavors, electron neutrino ($\nu_e$), muon neutrino ($\nu_\mu$), and tau neutrino ($\nu_\tau$)](figures/16/Neutrino-Oscillations.svg){#fig-neutrino-flavors fig-align="center"}
:::
:::
::: {.column width="65%"}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"}
![Coupled oscillators have different **modes** of oscillations. Watch the system shift from the left pendulum predominantly oscillating to the right one oscillating.](figures/16/phasing_pendula.gif){#fig-coupled-oscillators fig-align="center"}
:::
:::
